Award.AwardTitle: SBP: The Price of Parenting in STEM: Explaining Career Paths and Pay Consequences of Parenthood among Science and Engineering Professionals

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal was submitted in response to EHR Core Research (ECR) program announcement NSF 15-509. As part of ECR, this project is funded by the Research on Gender in Science and Engineering (GSE) program. GSE seeks to understand and address gender-based differences in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education and workforce participation through education and implementation research that will lead to a larger and more diverse domestic STEM workforce. Over the past two decades, social science research has found that girls and women encounter barriers in STEM education and then face additional obstacles entering and advancing in STEM careers. Yet, the effects of motherhood and fatherhood on the careers of STEM professionals are not well studied. This research will explore whether parenting--especially motherhood--incurs penalties in STEM employment in terms of retention, advancement, and salary. Using a sociological theoretical perspective that socially structured life courses move through gendered institutions, the study will examine how parenthood shapes career trajectories, retention, and salaries for women and men in STEM fields. The proposed empirical research project will use representative, longitudinal data to analyze these parenthood effects among STEM professionals. The researchers will also investigate how these parenthood effects differ by race/ethnicity, education level, sector, and STEM field. The findings will inform theory about gender differences in retention across all career stages and efforts to develop interventions that improve women's long-term persistence and success in STEM.

This project will use nationally representative, longitudinal, restricted-use data of STEM professionals from the Nation Center for Science and Engineering's (NCSES) Science and Engineering Statistical Data System (SESTAT) to examine the effects of parenthood on career paths and pay. The sample (N=17,599) includes STEM professionals employed full-time in 2003 and followed through 2010. Through a series of bi- and multivariate statistical analyses, the researchers will address the following research questions: Who leaves full-time STEM employment after becoming a parent? Where do they go? How do these parenthood effects vary by gender, race/ethnicity, education level, sector, and STEM field? Is the cost in lost income of making a career change higher if respondents made the change for family reasons compared to other reasons? Among workers who remain in full-time STEM careers, how do gender, parenthood, education level, and race/ethnicity affect salary? Since a large majority of workers become parents at some point during their careers, understanding the gendered effects of parenthood on the careers of STEM practitioners is central to understanding the retention of talented women and men in these fields. The researchers will also look for systematic variation by race/ethnicity, education level, sector and STEM field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project was to understand the potentially significant but understudied effects of parenthood on the career trajectories and salaries of women and men STEM professionals. Using restricted-use, longitudinal, nationally representative SESTAT data on STEM professionals, we investigated whether parenthood is an important point of departure from STEM, how this varies by gender, and whether there are career penalties among new parents.

The specific goals of this project were to: (1) Clean and code restricted-use data in preparation for analysis, (2) Analyze data following our hypotheses regarding the gendered and parenthood status effects on career trajectories of STEM professionals and resultant pay differentials; (3) Conceptualize, draft, and submit for publication scholarly articles based on findings, and (4) disseminate results via conferences, invited talks, and media.

We successfully completed each of these goals over the course of the funding period. We secured a license and access permissions to utilize the restricted-use SESTAT data, obtained necessary statistical and analytic training to appropriately deal with the complex data structure and replicate weights, and conducted analyses along the central hypotheses.

Our analyses produced the following novel findings. As documented in an article published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (Cech & Blair-Loy 2019; open-access), we find substantial and gendered attrition of new parents from full-time STEM employment. Specifically, we found that 43% of new mothers, and 23% of new fathers, are no longer employed full-time in STEM after the birth or adoption of their first child. These findings reveal not only that parenthood is an important driver of gender imbalance in STEM, but both mothers and fathers encounter challenges rectifying caregiving with STEM careers.

Further, in a paper in preparation for journal submission, we identified a new form of motherhood penalty: the shunting of new mothers out of the most prestigious ?core tasks? of their STEM professions after children. Specifically, we find that new mothers are more likely than similarly qualified new fathers to be diverted out of core tasks after children. This reveals a penalty that is not directly tied to, nor necessarily visible by salary differentials alone.

Additionally, in a working paper, we examine gendered patterns in the reasons why full-time STEM professionals report that they change jobs, and the gendered wage gaps that may be incurred by changing jobs for family reasons. Following STEM professionals who were employed full-time in STEM jobs in 2003 but changed jobs by 2010, we find that women are more likely than equally qualified men to change jobs for family reasons. And, when they do so, women incur $14,000 greater pay penalty on average than men who change jobs for family reasons.

Project findings, particularly from the 2019 PNAS article, have garnered a great deal of media attention. This article in particular had been downloaded more than 30,000 times by the end of the grant period and news articles covering or making reference to its findings appeared in Time Magazine, CNN, Forbes, Inside Higher Ed, Scientific American, and the news sections of Science and Nature. The PIs also presented results from this project at over a dozen conferences and invited lectures over the study period.

Intellectual Merit: This study is a new benchmark for scholarly research on gendered participation in the STEM workforce. Since a large majority of workers become parents at some point during their careers, understanding the gendered effects of parenthood on the career trajectories, retention, and pay of STEM practitioners is central to understanding the retention of talented women and men in these fields. It concretizes several of the multifaceted penalties (e.g., in persistence, in engagement in prestigious professional tasks) that mothers may face in their STEM careers. This project contributes to ECR's mission of promoting fundamental research on broadening participation in STEM and STEM workforce development.

 Broader Impacts: As indicated by the public and scholarly engagement with the 2019 PNAS article in particular, this project contributes to scholarly and policy understandings of the barriers to women's full participation in the STEM workforce. We have communicated our scholarly and policy-oriented results widely to both sociological and broader STEM audiences.  In addition to standard social scientific, peer-reviewed publications, we leveraged our university communications offices and national media contacts to expand the reach of this work beyond the confines of academia.  Our broad communication efforts support the efforts of scholars, STEM organization leaders, and policymakers to increase the retention of skilled women in STEM.
